results.title: Winners : Tarflowers (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Kev, and his dog, have a special job - to tend the Tarflowers. But his task is made difficult by Mrs. Pearl and her henchmen who catch stray people. However, Kev’s friend Mary, his mother and the garbage collectors know that the Tarflowers are really magic and that Kev isn’t as dumb as Mrs. Pearl thinks. Part of the “Winners” series.

results.title: Winners : Room to Move (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Carol is a dedicated runner, coached by her father, day and night. Then she makes friends with Angie, the new girl at school whose punk looks haven’t made her very popular. Angie introduces Carol to the wonderful world of dance. But Carol’s father won’t let her do anything that conflicts with her track-training. Parental pressure is tough on Carol who wants to succeed, but at several things. She rebels and plans a new life for herself. But the all-important race is coming up and Carol has to give it all she’s got. Part of the “Winners” series.

results.title: The Threepenny opera = L'opera de quat' sous. Die Dreigroschenoper
results.creator_credit: G Pabst, Seymour Nebenzal, Nero-Film, Tobis Filmkunst and Warner Brothers First National Productions
results.brief_description: In 19th Century London, Mack the Knife, a small-time criminal, marries Polly, the daughter of beggar-king, Peachum, and finds himself in a lot of trouble. In the early years of the sound era, film producers often made films in different language versions, using the same sets but different casts for each version. Pabst followed this practice with his twin versions of ‘The Threepenny Opera’ in German and French- ‘Die Driegroschenoper’(98 min.) and ‘L’Opera de Quat’ Sous’(105 min.). The two versions offer rich material for comparison. The German version was originally released in 1931 amidst political and legal controversy. The Nazis, rankled by its socialist message and attacks on government authority, ordered the destruction of the original negative and every print that could be found. The film’s unavailability bolstered its legendary status and, after many years of searching, a complete negative was found and a restored version released in 1960. Music by Kurt Weill. From the play by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill. In French and German with English subtitles.

Pabst followed this practice with his twin versions of ‘The Threepenny Opera’ in German and French- ‘Die Driegroschenoper’(98 min.) and ‘L’Opera de Quat’ Sous’(105 min.). The two versions offer rich material for comparison. The German version was originally released in 1931 amidst political and legal controversy. The film’s unavailability bolstered its legendary status and, after many years of searching, a complete negative was found and a restored version released in 1960. Music by Kurt Weill. From the play by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill. In French and German with English subtitles.

Pabst followed this practice with his twin versions of ‘The Threepenny Opera’ in German and French- ‘Die Driegroschenoper’(98 min.) and ‘L’Opera de Quat’ Sous’(105 min.). The two versions offer rich material for comparison. The German version was originally released in 1931 amidst political and legal controversy. results.title: Winners : Quest beyond time
results.creator_credit: Julia Overton, Richard Mason, Stephen Wallace and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
The Sickness has come to Clan Murray. They call on the gods for assistance, which arrives in the form of Mike and his hang-glider. He is the man who can fly. With Katrin of the Clan Murray he sets out on a quest for help through a savage land Australia in the post-nuclear Dark Age. Rated: G

results.title: The Three Stooges. Vols. 17,18,21
results.brief_description: Compilation of three videos starring the Three Stooges in some of their funniest films. Titles include “Crash goes the hash” (dir. Jules White); “Three pests in a mess” (dir. Del Lord); “Three trouble dooers” (dir. Edward Bernds); “Rusty romeos” (dir. Jules White); “Merry mixup” (dir. Jules White); “Quizz wizz” (dir. Jules White); “Slippery silks” (dir. Jack White); “Flat foot Stooges” (dir. Charley Chase); “Whoops I’m an Indian” (dir. Del Lord). The Three Stooges consisted of Moe Howard, Shemp Howard and Larry Fine.

results.title: Winners : Quest beyond time (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A flight on his hang glider sends Mike 500 years into a post-nuclear Dark Age. When a Chieftain tells him of the Holocaust he’s convinced he’s landed in a lunatic asylum. The Clan Murray are victims of the Sickness and Mike agrees to accompany a young woman warrior on a quest with many dangers. Finally they must cross a sea of nuclear waste to find a cure. Part of the “Winners” series.

results.title: Winners : On Loan (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Bennett, Jane Scott, Patricia Edgar and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Vietnamese born, Lindy, is adopted by an Australian family who believe she is an orphan. Following her fourteenth birthday, she receives a letter from her natural father. Lindy has to decide between two families and two futures, Australia or Vietnam. Part of the “Winners” Series.

results.title: The Three Stooges. Vols 24-26
results.brief_description: Compilation of three videos starring the Three Stooges in some of their funniest films. Titles include “Nutty but nice” (dir. Jules White); Gripes, grunts & groans” (dir. Jack White); “Three little pirates (dir. Edward Bernds); “Horsing around” (dir. Jules White); “Hoofs and goofs” (dir. Jules White); “Flying saucer Daffey” (dir. Jules White); “Guns a poppin” (dir. Jules White); “Sweet and hot” (dir. Jules White); “Bubble & trouble” (1953). The Three Stooges consisted of Moe Howard, Shemp Howard and Larry Fine.

results.title: TV sale
results.creator_credit: Ernie Schmidt, Don Worobey, John Taylor, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The opening pitch of the television salesman pretty well establishes the tone of this pithy animation film: a solid-state model guarantees high-quality entertainment. TV Sale is an entertaining, incisive and horrifying satire on some of the material that is disgorged via the “boob tube.” Programs are designed around the product, not the spectator.
